abstracts.cdata!:
The mitigation plan for this
            environmental assessment focuses on proper handling of
            hazardous and infection, covering areas like source of
            waste; quantity of waste generated; and method of
            segregation, disinfection, transportation, and disposal.
            Field staff at community-based programs for injecting drug
            users will do the following when handling and disposing of
            sharps and syringes: avoid accidental pricking, avoid
            leaving unpacked syringes and sharps unguarded, use needle
            cutter boxes to decapitate syringes immediately, collect the
            plastic body of the syringe in a coded bag, wear
            non-pierceable gloves when handling the sharps and needle
            containers, transfer needles and sharps in
            puncture-resistant containers or disinfection vessel,
            disinfect as per guidelines as given with disinfectant
            bleach, seal the code coded bags containing syringes and
            send them to a deep burial site for final disposal.
            Personnel in-charge will provide posters at needle exchange
            places indicating the methods of use and cleansing and
            disposal of syringes. Lab technicians and nurses will handle
            and safely dispose of blood bank material at teaching and
            district hospitals. they will avoid accidentally pricking
            themselves or their patients with needles and sharps; avoid
            leaving blood bags and transfusion tubing unguarded; use
            needle cutter boxes to remove needles from transfusion
            tubing; and collect blood bags and transfusion tubing in
            coded bags. Blood bags will be disinfected in microwave
            ovens and buried.
